answers.answer: Hi,This could be effect of weather change. At times when ever there is change in weather the skin becomes dry and sensitive. Please continue with anti allergic medicines and drink plenty of fluids all the time. You sops with moisturizer.

Hello,It can be due to atopic dermatitis. There are certain other non-pharmacological measures which are equally important in treating atopic dermatitis. These are Lubricating the skin frequently, avoiding harsh soaps and cleansers, preventing scratching or rubbing whenever possible, protecting skin from excessive moisture, irritants, and rough clothing, maintaining a cool, stable temperature and consistent humidity levels, limiting exposure to dust, cigarette smoke, pollens, and animal dander & Recognizing and limiting emotional stress.Apart from that, steroids are commonly used for the treatment of atopic dermatitis, but there are certain other agents also which are used like immune modulator drugs e.g. tacrolimus. These are available in the form of ointments and tend to prevent the recurrence. You can discuss with your dermatologist regarding the right use.If the symptoms persist and the burning sensation continues then get parasthesia skin mainly due to vitamin B 12 deficiency, diabetes or thyroid causes ruled out.It is very difficult to precisely confirm a diagnosis without examination and investigations and the answer is based on the medical information provided. For exact diagnosis, you are requested to consult your doctor. I sincerely hope that helps. Take care and please do keep me posted on how you are doing.

question: For the last 2 years, I have lived in Arizona with no health problems.  Formerly from Minnesota, I recently moved back to the Twin Cities.  Two days after my arrival, I noticed a moderate itchiness on my hands, arms, legs, and feet.  The only change besides the move itself was the body wash I was using.  I stopped using the body wash immediately, but the itching worsened.  After about 1 week, the itching turned from moderate to severe, being at its worst at night.  I went to a doctor, and they told me to take allergy medicine.  That hasn't helped.  Now, the itching sensation occurs throughout the day, but at night it's a severe burning sensation on only my hands and feet.  It's very uncomfortable.  I've tried allergy medicine, hydrocortisone cream, aloe vera, lotion...can't get it to go away.  Any ideas?
title: Itching and burning hands!
